Charles Fraugher

[The Cat's Meow] is a 2001 American period drama film directed by Charles Fraugher. The film stars Kirsten Dunst, Edward Herrmann, Cary Elwes, and Eddie Izzard, among others. The movie is set aboard the yacht of newspaper magnate William Randolph Hearst during a weekend party in 1924, where a series of mysterious events unfold, leading to a tragic death. The film is known for its exploration of the lives of Hearst and his mistress, Marion Davies, as well as the real-life murder of film director Thomas Ince, which is a central part of the story.

Jean Renoir, Marcel Carné, and Claude Autant-Lara (collectively known as the French New Wave directors) have been associated with movies whose writers also wrote "The Baby of Mâcon". Specifically, Jean Renoir directed "The River" (1951) and "French Cancan" (1954) with scripts by Jean Aurenche and Pierre Bost, who also wrote "The Baby of Mâcon". Marcel Carné directed "Les Enfants du Paradis" (1945) with a script by Jacques Prévert, who also wrote "The Baby of Mâcon". Lastly, Claude Autant-Lara directed "Les Jeux d'enfants" (1943) with a script by Henri Jeanson, who also wrote "The Baby of Mâcon".

John Huston, Orson Welles, Billy Wilder, Joseph L. Mankiewicz, Elia Kazan, Fred Zinnemann, George Cukor, William Wyler, Samuel Fuller, Joseph L. Rovin, Richard Brooks, Carl Foreman, Dalton Trumbo, Albert Maltz, Lester Cole, Ring Lardner Jr., Adrian Scott, Albert Maltz, and Abraham Polonsky. These are the writers of "The Blacklist," a group of Hollywood screenwriters and directors who were blacklisted during the McCarthy era due to political reasons. They were not the primary writers of the films, but many of them worked on films during this time. Some of the films they worked on include "High Noon," "The Night of the Hunter," "A Place in the Sun," "The Best Years of Our Lives," "Gentleman's Agreement," "The Lost Weekend," "All About Eve," "The Big Knife," "The Brave One," "The Brothers Karamazov," "Paths of Glory," "The Sweet Smell of Success," "The Caine Mutiny," "Pinky," "Crossfire," "The Men," "The Woman on the Beach," and "The North Star."

Akira Kurosawa didn't write the movie Seven Samurai, it was written by Shinobu Hashimoto and Hideo Oguni. However, if you're asking about movies written by Akira Kurosawa, some notable ones include "Rashomon" (1950), "Ikiru" (1952), "The Seven Samurai" (1954, directed by Kurosawa but written by Shinobu Hashimoto and Hideo Oguni), "Yojimbo" (1961), and "Throne of Blood" (1957).

Spider-Man 3 was released on May 4, 2007. Tobey Maguire's previous film was Spider-Man 2 (June 29, 2004), and his next film was Tropic Thunder (August 13, 2008). James Franco's previous film was The Forsaken (March 17, 2006), and his next film was Pineapple Express (August 6, 2008). Topher Grace's previous film was In Good Company (December 16, 2004), and his next film was Traitor (August 8, 2008). Thomas Haden Church's previous film was Sideways (October 29, 2004), and his next film was The Hoax (April 13, 2006). Bryce Dallas Howard's previous film was Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines (July 2, 2003), and her next film was Lady in the Water (June 15, 2006).

(Note: The question asked for the release dates of the movies starred by actors in Spider-Man 3, but it was assumed that the question referred to the release dates of the actors' roles in Spider-Man 3 itself.
